titleStmt.title: Here follow certaine other verses, as charmes, to vnlocke the misterie of the Crudities.
titleStmt.author: Jonson, Ben

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: Here follow certaine other verses, as charmes, to vnlocke the misterie of the Crudities.
analytic.author: Jonson, Ben

monogr.title: The Odcombian banquet: dished foorth by Thomas the Coriat, and serued in by a number of noble wits in prayse of his Crudities and Crambe too. Asinus portans mysteria

div.head: Here follow certaine other verses, as charmes, to vnlocke the misterie of the Crudities.
A
div.l: HEre, like Arion, our Coryate doth draw
All sorts of fish with Musicke of his maw.

div.head: B
div.l: HEre not vp Holdborne, but downe a steepe hill,

He's carried' twixt Montrel and
〈◊〉 .

div.head: C
div.l: A Horse here'ts sadled, but no Tom him to backe,
It should rather haue beene Tom that a horse did lacke.

div.head: D
div.l: HEre vp the Alpes (not so plaine as to Dunstable)
He's carried like a Cripple, from Constable to Constable.

div.head: E
div.l: A Punke here pelts him with egs. How so?
For he did but kisse her, and so let her goe.

div.head: F
div.l: Religiously here he bids, row from the stewes,
He will expiate this sinne with conuerting the Iewes

div.head: G
div.l: ANd there, while he giues the zealous Brauado,
A Rabbin confutes him with the Bastinado.

div.head: H
div.l: HEre, by a Boore too, hee's like to be beaten
For Grapes he had gather'd before they were eaten.

div.head: I
div.l: OLd Hat here, torne Hose, with Shoes ful of grauel,
And louse-dropping case, are the Armes of his trauel.

div.head: K
div.l: HEre, finer then comming from his Punke you 〈◊〉 see,

Not meaning by F. and K. as the vulgar may peeuishly & wittingly mistake: but that hee was then comming from his curtesan, a fresh. man, and 〈◊〉 hauing seene their fashiens, and written a description of them, He will shortly be reputed a knowing, proper, and wel traueled scholler, as by 〈◊〉 starchd beard, and printed ruffe may bee as properly insinuated. F. shewes what he was, K, what he will bee.

div.head: L
div.l: HEre France, and Italy both to him shed
Their hornes, and Germany pukes on his head.

div.head: M
div.l: ANd here he disdaind not, in a forraine land
To lie at Liuory, while the Horses did stand.

div.head: N
div.l: BVt here, neither trusting his hands, nor his legs.
Being in feare to be robd, be most learnedly begs.
